title: Economic Outlook: Minimum Wage Hike, Inflation Concerns, and Infrastructure Investment Highlighted
subtitle: Report automatically generated on 2026-01-12 by the Trade Section, EU Delegation to Colombia
summary: The Colombian economic landscape is marked by a significant 23% increase in the minimum wage for 2026, leading to concerns about inflation and increased costs for businesses and consumers alike, particularly in the restaurant sector [[REF:677d8039-b38f-4caa-bf17-eea4e821795d]]. The government is attempting to mitigate some of these effects by proposing regulations to decouple housing prices from minimum wage indexing and ensure consumer protection [[REF:0efea05a-a950-4a24-a476-69786837741a]][[REF:77f5c0fe-4186-4e9f-b785-dcf675841a6a]][[REF:4cd41845-7a5d-4f49-896e-db2b9127cdf4]]. Experts predict continued economic pressures with inflation and interest rates remaining key factors for the year [[REF:1b637b3c-dc79-426e-8112-cd22b041bfee]]. Meanwhile, infrastructure development is ongoing, with the IDU achieving its highest budget execution in over a decade, securing projects for Bogotá [[REF:5620bbaa-cc8f-4840-ac11-ddd30b23fc9f]].

sections.title: Economic Impact of Minimum Wage Increase and Inflation Concerns
sections.body: The Colombian economy is facing significant adjustments due to a substantial 23% increase in the minimum wage for 2026 [[REF:51560711-334c-410f-a8ee-760d0d16291f]]. This rise is projected to have a ripple effect across various sectors, with restaurants, in particular, warning of potential closures, menu changes, and layoffs due to increased payroll costs [[REF:677d8039-b38f-4caa-bf17-eea4e821795d]]. The popular 'corrientazo' lunch may also see price hikes as businesses grapple with higher operational expenses [[REF:e0e09746-23f8-4184-b6f4-85e4d9753d98]]. The government, recognizing these challenges, is taking steps to mitigate the impact. A draft decree aims to prevent Social Interest Housing (VIS) prices from being indexed to the minimum wage, requiring instead that they be set in Colombian pesos [[REF:0efea05a-a950-4a24-a476-69786837741a]][[REF:4cd41845-7a5d-4f49-896e-db2b9127cdf4]][[REF:89c612ef-1c90-4326-aa81-547e5925e3b8]]. This move seeks to protect homebuyers from automatic price increases tied to the minimum wage [[REF:77f5c0fe-4186-4e9f-b785-dcf675841a6a]]. President Petro has also urged property owner assemblies to base administration fee increases on inflation rather than arbitrary hikes [[REF:97a7688e-94a8-416f-bb86-66f53ab8fde3]]. Despite these measures, expert forecasts suggest continued economic pressures, with inflation and interest rates remaining critical factors influencing the economic landscape throughout 2026 [[REF:1b637b3c-dc79-426e-8112-cd22b041bfee]][[REF:475caf6f-7738-446a-9650-5c516a0651fd]].

sections.title: Infrastructure Development and Investment
sections.body: Progress continues on key infrastructure projects, with the Urban Development Institute (IDU) reporting its highest budget execution in over a decade for 2025 [[REF:5620bbaa-cc8f-4840-ac11-ddd30b23fc9f]]. This strong performance has secured funding and enabled the advancement of various infrastructure projects across Bogotá, including roadworks and public space improvements, with further interventions planned for 2026 [[REF:5620bbaa-cc8f-4840-ac11-ddd30b23fc9f]]. The Mayor of Bogotá, Carlos Fernando Galán, announced the completion of the concrete structure for a critical vehicular bridge on First of May Avenue, a significant step for the city's mobility and a key component for Line 1 of the Bogotá Metro [[REF:e6a81692-cdce-44c9-b160-ab004e6bba05]][[REF:ef330444-d285-4a06-b4ab-67310d83c289]]. These developments signal continued investment in urban infrastructure and connectivity.

sections.title: Financial Markets and Foreign Investment Outlook
sections.body: Experts are forecasting a dynamic financial market in 2026, with key indicators such as the dollar exchange rate and interest rates remaining under close observation [[REF:90b1bf68-f387-473d-aebc-f2528c13983b]][[REF:1b637b3c-dc79-426e-8112-cd22b041bfee]]. The price of oil is expected to trade between $55 and $60 per barrel, influenced by global supply and demand dynamics, with potential impacts on energy-dependent economies [[REF:4db8d69c-62e3-4325-a18c-d9a7e95bc9dd]]. In terms of foreign investment, the Mexican fintech unicorn Stori has received authorization from Colombia's Financial Superintendence to establish operations, marking a notable expansion into the Colombian financial services sector [[REF:8b1ec07c-3604-4a33-805e-eb32e51e8512]]. The government's financial management is also under scrutiny, with the Comptroller's Office investigating potential fiscal damage and contractual flaws related to assets managed by the SAE in Medellín [[REF:dd336b7b-e0a2-4691-ac94-0269ad4a14a4]].

sections.title: Political and Security Developments
sections.body: In domestic politics, President Gustavo Petro has faced criticism regarding a controversial $10 billion contract for his defense related to US sanctions, with political figures questioning the use of state funds [[REF:584ccfa8-d455-4562-8dfd-c8061f5431df]][[REF:47c1bae6-f870-4c5e-a631-69917280514a]][[REF:52ca7064-50ca-45a9-a598-9dfbead7f1eb]]. The upcoming congressional elections on March 8th are being described as potentially under a "terrorist siege," emphasizing the need for congressional support and a strong relationship with the United States [[REF:1c27a6a8-62e5-4dd1-a4aa-d460b7dd0516]]. On the security front, the Minister of Defense highlighted the strengthening of relations with the US as crucial for more effective action against drug trafficking [[REF:261befe7-e6be-41fc-a542-f1ddc70d2422]]. International relations remain a key focus, with discussions around potential coordinated military operations against the ELN involving the United States, Venezuela, and Colombia [[REF:44f116e2-ddcf-43dc-b240-f220af093a78]].
